keyint.name: Maximum Key Frame Interval
keyint.Advanced: Defines the maximum size of a Group of Pictures. A frame in a GOP cannot reference frames in other GOPs, and in doing so enables seeking and random access. GOP sizes are dynamically calculated during encoding to maximise compression, however specifying a maximum GOP prevents any reduction of seekability.

min-keyint.name: Minimum Key Frame Interval
min-keyint.Advanced: Defines the minimum size of a Group of Pictures. A frame in a GOP cannot reference frames in other GOPs, and in doing so enables seeking and random access. GOP sizes are dynamically calculated during encoding to maximise compression, however specifying a minimum GOP will help improve compression in high motion scenes.

scenecut.name: Scene Change Sensitivity
scenecut.Advanced: Modifies the sensitivity to scene changes. Scene change detection is useful as it forces the use of an I-frame at a scene change, leading to better looking cuts and overall improvement in quality.
scenecut.Basic: How aggressively scene changes are detected

bframes.name: Maximum B-frames
bframes.Advanced: Bi-directional Predictive Frames are highly compressed as they only store the data that has changed from the previous frame or that is different from the next frame. B-frames generally have less quality than I- or P- frames but can increase the overall quality of the video by storing data very efficiently. A setting of 2 to 3 will usually provide a good overall quality while allowing significant compression advantages.
bframes.Basic: Maximum number of B-frames between I and P frames

b-adapt.name: Adaptive B-frames
b-adapt.Advanced: Enables x264 to make adaptive decisions on where B-frames should be used, decreasing the number of consecutive B-frames where it makes sense.

b-bias.name: B-frame Bias
b-bias.Advanced: Positive values increase the likelihood that a B-frame will be used, negative values decrease the likelihood, without violating the "Maximum B-frames" setting.
b-bias.Basic: Influences how often B-frames are used

b-pyramid.name: B-frame Pyramid
b-pyramid.Advanced: Allows B-frames to be used as references for other B-frames, increasing compression efficiency when 2 or more B-frames are used.

no-cabac.name: Encode CABAC
no-cabac.Advanced: CABAC is a clever technique of losslessly compressing the syntax elements of the video stream, knowing the probabilities of the elements in a given context. CABAC uses more CPU for encoding and decoding. When disabled, video is encoded using CAVLC (Context Adaptive Variable Length Encoding) which is less CPU intensive but provides less compression. Note: Some advanced features will not be available when encoding with CAVLC.
no-cabac.Basic: Encode with Context Adaptive Binary Arithmetic Coding to increase compression

ref.name: Reference Frames
ref.Advanced: Determines how many previous frames can be referenced by a P- or B-frame. Encoding slows as more frames are used. The maximum value is 16, however quality increases become marginal with more than 5 reference frames.

nf.name: Deblocking (in loop) Filter
nf.Advanced: MPEG-4 AVC defines video with a grid of squares representing moving data, the in loop deblocking filter detects the edges of these squares in order to smooth them. In loop deblocking is part of the normal operation of MPEG-4 AVC and should not be disabled.

filter.name: Deblocking (in loop) Filter Strength
filter.Advanced: Deblocking strength is computed for each macroblock according to the quantizer of the macroblock and that of its neighbours. Alpha is used to determine whether the frontier of an encoded macroblock is blocky or if it's actually a detail. It works like a threshold. Beta also works like a threshold, but is used to insure that the picture is homogenous on both sides of the frontier in order to separate detail from blockiness. When blocks are detected, alpha is used to decide the strength (maximum allowed modification of the pixel). Beta applies slight modification to this strength if the macroblock is homogenous.
filter.Basic: Deblocking Strength : Deblocking Threshold (strength : threshold). The Deblocking Threshold determines how easily the filter detects blocks. The Deblocking Strength determines how strong detected blocks should be deblocked. The default provides an accurate mix of deblocking while preserving detail. Adjustments should range from -3 to 3 (lower values indicate less deblocking. Negative values do not indicate the deblocking effect is reversed). Note: Setting values too high will result in loss of detail and texture or smearing. Setting the value to low may leave sharp edges or mosquito noise. There should be a positive correlation between each setting, ie. if you apply heavier deblocking, you should increase the threshold so that more data is deblocked.

qp.name: Constant Quantizer
qp.Advanced: In Constant Quantizer mode, each frame is encoded with the same mathematical quality (or quantizer) as every other frame, regardless of the bit rate required to do so, applying a constant mathematical quality to the entire video sequence. Lower values indicate lower compression (higher quality). There is no way to predict file size in this mode. Note: Values under 15 are only useful for archival/reproduction quality and values over 40 show considerable loss in quality.
qp.Basic: Encode in Constant Quality mode (0 = lossless) regardless of bit rate. Note: This mode only requires 1 pass.

bitrate.name: Average Bit Rate
bitrate.Advanced: In Average (Variable) Bit Rate mode (VBR), each frame is encoded at the lowest possible quantizer (best quality) while maintaining the average bit rate specified over time. File size can be predicted in this mode. Note: Other VBV settings determine the level of change in local bit rate used to compensate for changing scene complexity.
bitrate.Basic: Sets the average bit rate that the file is to be encoded in. Note: this mode performs best in 2 passes.

crf.name: Quality Based VBR
crf.Advanced: In Constant Quality Based VBR mode, each frame is encoded with almost the same mathematical quality (or quantizer) as every other frame, taking motion (rate control) into account. This mode improves visual quality by encoding high motion scenes with slightly higher compression (lower quality) and low motion scenes with slightly lower compression (higher quality). While the quantizer (mathematical quality) may fluctuate over time, less bits are spent on scenes where high speed fine detail would be invisible, and more bits are spent in scenes where more static fine detail is more visible. This applies a constant visual quality to the entire video sequence. Lower values indicate lower compression (higher quality). There is no way to predict file size in this mode. Note: Values under 15 are only useful for archival/reproduction quality and values over 40 show considerable loss in quality. This mode is only tuned for qcomp=0.6.
crf.Basic: Encode in Quality Based Variable Bit Rate mode, regardless of bit rate. Note: This mode can perform best in 2 passes.

qpmin.name: Minimum Quantizer
qpmin.Advanced: Enforces a minimum Quantizer. Prevents the codec from outputting frames with too little compression, wasting bits. Note: This is disregarded in Constant Quality or Quality Based VBR modes.

qpmax.name: Maximum Quantizer
qpmax.Advanced: Enforces a maximum Quantizer. Prevents the codec from outputting frames with too much compression, causing reduced quality. Note: This is disregarded in Constant Quality or Quality Based VBR modes.

qpstep.name: Maximum Quantizer Steps
qpstep.Advanced: Sets how much the quantizer can change between consecutive frames, maintaining a more stable level of quality.

ratetol.name: Average Bit rate Variance (%)
ratetol.Advanced: Regulates how much the bit rate can fluctuate from the target Average Bit Rate that has been set. Lower settings constrict bit rate changes, producing a file that will stream better and more closely match a predicted file size based on the set bit rate, while reducing the codec's ability to adapt to complex scenes. Higher settings increase bit rate variability which decreases the reliability of streaming and the ability to predict the file size, while improving the codec's ability to adapt to complex scenes. Setting this to 0% would result in a constant bit rate. Setting this to 100% would provide a highly erratic bit rate dependant on scene complexity. (A setting of 100% would result in Constant Quantizer compression.
ratetol.Basic: Allowed variance of average bit rate. Lower values indicate less variance, while higher values indicate more variance.

vbv-maxrate.name: VBV Maximum Bit rate
vbv-maxrate.Advanced: Specifies the maximum bit rate allowed in the Video Buffer.
vbv-maxrate.Basic: Max local bit rate of Video Buffer Verifier.

vbv-bufsize.name: VBV Buffer Size
vbv-bufsize.Advanced: Specifies the maximum size of the Video Buffer, which can affect playback start up times if too large and cause stuttering if too small.

vbv-init.name: VBV Initial Size
vbv-init.Advanced: Specifies the level of the Video Buffer to fill before playback can begin. Low levels may cause reduced initial quality while high levels may cause artificially high initial quality.

ipratio.name: I-P Quantizer Factor
ipratio.Advanced: Specifies the level of quality reduction between high quality I-frames and the more compressed P-frames that follow.
ipratio.Basic: Quantization factor used between I- and P-frames.

pbratio.name: P-B Quantizer Factor
pbratio.Advanced: Specifies the level of quality reduction between P-frames and the more compressed B-frames that follow.
pbratio.Basic: Quantization factor between P- and B-frames.

chroma-qp-offset.name: Chroma and Luma Quantizer Offset
chroma-qp-offset.Advanced: Specifies the level of quality reduction between colour and brightness information. The human eye is more sensitive to changes in brightness than colour, so compression can be increased by removing some colour detail.
chroma-qp-offset.Basic: Quantization difference between chroma (colour) and luma (brightness) values.

pass.name: Multipass Mode
pass.Advanced: Multiple passes allow the codec to make more informed choices when deciding how to compress each frame in regards to the quality and complexity of the entire clip. Note: 2 pass encoding will take up to twice as long.
pass.Basic: Enable multipass rate control for Average Bit Rate or Quality based VBR modes.

stats.name: Statistics File Name
stats.Advanced: This file holds information generated about each frame, which is then used to make more informed choices on the finial pass.

qcomp.name: Quantizer Curve Compression
qcomp.Advanced: Regulates how much the quality can fluctuate within the target Average Bit Rate that has been set. Higher settings constrict quality changes, producing a file that will have a more constant quality throughout, while reducing the codec's ability to adapt to complex scenes where loss of detail may not be as important. Lower settings increase variability of quality, which may improve visual quality throughout the video by reducing quality where fine detail can't be seen and increasing it where fine detail is more noticeable. Setting this to 1 would result in constant quality. Setting this to 0 would create highly erratic quality changes.
qcomp.Basic: Allowed variance of average quantizer (or quality). Higher values indicate less variance, while lower values indicate more variance. Note: 1 indicates constant quality while 0 indicates maximum fluctuation.

cplxblur.name: Quantizer Fluctuation Reduction (Before)
cplxblur.Basic: Reduce fluctuations in Quantizer (before curve compression).

qblur.name: Quantizer Fluctuation Reduction (After)
qblur.Basic: Reduce fluctuations in QP (after curve compression).

zones.name: Define Zones
zones.Advanced: Zones allow you to define areas of video for which you can specify additional encoding options. eg you may specify the credits at the end of the film to use a lower bit rate or higher compression than the main feature.
zones.Basic: Define regions of video for which additional encoding options can be specified.

analyse.name: Macroblock Analysis Sizes
analyse.Advanced: Enabling additional macroblock search sizes increases encoding efficiency and quality but decreases speed. Note: i8x8 can only be used in High Profile and when Adaptive 8x8 DCT is used.
analyse.Basic: Specify which Macroblock Partition Sizes to analyse

direct.name: B-frame Mode
direct.Advanced: Determines how motion vectors for B-frames are derived. Spatial uses neighbouring blocks in the same frame which may result in higher PSNR. Temporal makes use of neighbouring frames which may be perceived as higher quality. Auto selects direct mode per frame. Works best in 2pass (enable in both passes).

weightb.name: B-frame Weighted Prediction
weightb.Advanced: Enables 'brightness' weighting of B-frames which improves fades and colour gradients ie sky.

me.name: Motion Estimation Mode
me.Advanced: Controls the method used to search for motion vectors. Diamond search radius 1 (fastest), hexagonal search radius 2 (fast), uneven multi-hexagon search (slow), exhaustive search (slowest). Exhaustive search is not recommended for normal use as it is exceptionally slow and does not provide significant quality increases.

merange.name: Maximum Motion Vector Range
merange.Advanced: Specifies the maximum range a macroblock can travel in order to be encoded as a vector. Larger values may increase efficiency but will increase encoding time.

subme.name: Sub Pixel Refinement
subme.Advanced: Controls the decision quality of motion estimation. Lower values will make faster and less accurate decisions. Higher values will improve quality but will slow encoding speed.
subme.Basic: Sub Pixel motion estimation and partition decision quality: 1=fast, 9=best.

mixed-refs.name: Mixed References
mixed-refs.Advanced: Allows each 8x8 or 16x8 partition in a macroblock to independently select a reference frame, as opposed to only one reference frame per macroblock.
mixed-refs.Basic: Decide references on a per partition basis

no-chroma-me.name: Chroma Motion Estimation
no-chroma-me.Advanced: Enables Motion Estimation to take colour components of the video into account when calculating movement, improving quality.

i8x8dct.name: Adaptive 8x8 DCT
i8x8dct.Advanced: Enables the intelligent adaptive use of 8x8 transforms in I-frames. Requires I8X8 checked.

i4x4mv.name: 4x4 sub-partitions for I-Frames
i4x4mv.Advanced: Enables the use of 4x4 sub-partitions in predicted macroblocks, for I-frames.

p4x4mv.name: 4x4 sub-partitions for P-Frames
p4x4mv.Advanced: Enables the use of 4x4 sub-partitions in predicted macroblocks, for P-frames. Improves compression by about 0.5%, at the cost of encoding speed. Requires P8X8 enabled.

p8x8mv.name: 8x8 sub-partitions for P-Frames
p8x8mv.Advanced: Enables the use of 8x8 sub-partitions in predicted macroblocks, for P-frames.

b8x8mv.name: 8x8 sub-partitions for B-Frames
b8x8mv.Advanced: Enables the use of 8x8 sub-partitions in predicted macroblocks, for B-frames.

i8x8mv.name: 8x8 sub-partitions for I-Frames
i8x8mv.Advanced: Enables the use of 8x8 sub-partitions in predicted macroblocks, for I-frames.

trellis.name: Trellis Quantization
trellis.Advanced: Performs Trellis quantization to increase efficiency. On Macroblock provides a good compromise between speed and efficiency. On all decisions reduces speed further.
trellis.Basic: Trellis Rate Distortion quantization. (Requires CABAC, disables deadzone)

psyrd.name: Psychovisual RD optimizations
psyrd.Advanced: Modifies the rate-distortion metric to improve sharpness and detail retention.

psytrellis.name: Psychovisual Trellis optimizations
psytrellis.Advanced: Experimental: attempts to improve sharpness beyond that of the ordinary trellis algorithm. Your mileage may vary.

no-fast-pskip.name: Fast P-frame Skip Detection
no-fast-pskip.Advanced: Fast Skip detection increases speed but may cause slight blockiness in areas of solid colour or slight gradients such as dark scenes or sky. Enabling this option will DISABLE the Fast Skip detection.
no-fast-pskip.Basic: Disables early Skip detection on P-frames.

nr.name: Noise Reduction
nr.Advanced: Estimates film noise based on this value and attempts to remove it by dropping small details before quantization. This may not match the quality of a good external noise reduction filter, but it performs very fast.

cqmfile.name: Quantization Matrice File
cqmfile.Basic: Read quantization matrices from a JM compatible file. (Overrides any other --cqm* options).

cqm4.name: 4x4 Quantization Matrices
cqm4.Advanced: Takes a comma separated list of 16 integers.

cqm8.name: 8x8 Quantization Matrices
cqm8.Advanced: Takes a comma separated list of 64 integers.

sar.name: Sample Aspect Ratio
sar.Advanced: Stores the size of non-square pixels in the video stream for use during playback. This enables anamorphic video.

level.name: AVC Complexity Level
level.Basic: Specify level (as defined by Annex A)

fps.name: Frame Rate
fps.Advanced: This can be used to change the frame rate of the video during encoding (or specify the frame rate for a source that does not detect correctly).

seek.name: Seek to Start Frame
seek.Advanced: Enables encoding to begin at any point in the source.

frames.name: Frames to Encode
frames.Advanced: Enables encoding to finish at a point before the end of the source.
frames.Basic: Maximum number of frames to encode

threads.name: Number of Threads
threads.Advanced: For optimum speed, this should be left at 0, ie automatic detection. The automatic setting is 1.5 x logical CPUs. Threads increase encoding speed and negligibly negatively affect quality.
threads.Basic: Enable parallel encoding by using more than 1 thread to increase speed

no-asm.name: CPU Optimizations
no-asm.Advanced: Codecs use advanced CPU SIMD (Single Instruction, Multiple Data) instruction sets allowing massive speed increases. This should only be enabled for troubleshooting purposes.

psnr.name: PSNR Computation
psnr.Advanced: Prevents PSNR calculations that are reported on completion.

ssim.name: SSIM Computation
ssim.Advanced: Prevents SSIM calculations that are reported on completion.

losslessmode.name: Lossless Mode
losslessmode.Advanced: Set QP to 0 to activate the lossless Mode.

fourcc.name: The FourCC
fourcc.Advanced: Specify the AVC FourCC you what you want. Depends mostly on the decoder used.

quiet.name: Quiet Mode
quiet.Basic: Enable Quiet Mode (do not display output information).

progress.name: Progress Meter
progress.Basic: Show a progress indicator while encoding.

visualize.name: Visualize Analysis
visualize.Advanced: Debugging option used to understand what is happening on a frame by frame basis.
visualize.Basic: Show Macroblock types overlayed on the encoded video.

aud.name: Access Unit Delimiters
aud.Advanced: Used for compatibility when using AVC in some transport streams (inc MPEG-2 TS).

aqmode.name: AQ Mode
aqmode.Advanced: This option controls how AQ distributes bits. Mode 0 disables the feature whereas Mode 1 enables Variance AQ (complexity mask).
aqmode.Basic: The Mode of the Adaptive Quantizers

aqstrength.name: AQ Strength
aqstrength.Advanced: Reduces blocking and blurring in flat and textured areas. To have a weak AQ choose 0.5 and a strong one 1.5 as value.

profile.name: AVC Profiles
profile.Advanced: The H.264 standard includes the following sets of capabilities, which are referred to as profiles, targeting specific classes of applications: - Baseline Profile (BP): Primarily for lower-cost applications with limited computing resources, this profile is used widely in videoconferencing and mobile applications. - Main Profile (MP): Originally intended as the mainstream consumer profile for broadcast and storage applications, the importance of this profile faded when the High profile was developed for those applications. - Extended Profile (XP): Intended as the streaming video profile, this profile has relatively high compression capability and some extra tricks for robustness to data losses and server stream switching. - High Profile (HiP): The primary profile for broadcast and disc storage applications, particularly for high-definition television applications (this is the profile adopted into HD DVD and Blu-ray Disc, for example).

presetList.name: info
presetList.Basic: To import all presets in once, right click on this list and select all...

presetList.name: info
presetList.Basic: To export all presets in once, right click on this list and select all...
